properties.description: Salt merchant-funded troupes (e.g., Chuntai Troupe) fused Anqing Mandarin with Suzhou Kunqu, giving rise to Ruantan, an early form of Peking Opera.
properties.contribution: Blended Mandarin and Wu dialects to form transitional opera styles

properties.description: While Kunqu was originally sung in Wu dialect, by the Qing dynasty, to appeal to northern audiences, jing (painted-face) and chou (comic) roles began using Mandarin, as noted in Lüyuan Conghua.
properties.contribution: Introduced Mandarin into Kunqu role speech

properties.description: While Kunqu was originally sung in Wu dialect, by the Qing dynasty, to appeal to northern audiences, jing (painted-face) and chou (comic) roles began using Mandarin, as noted in Lüyuan Conghua.
properties.contribution: Spread Mandarin in operatic performance through audience-sensitive roles

properties.description: Boatmen and guards from the north brought retroflex sounds and words like “ǎn” to Xuzhou. Meanwhile, southern workers introduced Wu dialect terms, making Xuzhou a blend of northern and southern speech along the canal.
properties.contribution: Created mixed dialect blending northern and southern features
